answers.answer: I agree that you should be concerned about your own risk of cardiovascular disease after your brother's heart issues.  While I think the smoking was a major risk factor which you do NOT share, the family history, obesity and hypertension are very important issues.  You cannot do anything about family history, but the rest are all areas to be addressed.  I would recommend the following:1. Diet and exercise with aim for significant weight loss (BMI to 25-30).2. Check your cholesterol and make sure you know the goal numbers.  I would strongly consider going on a statin medication IF your LDL is too high.3. Check your hemoglobin A1c, which tracks long-term blood sugar levels in the body. IF you have signs of insulin resistance or early diabetes, then you should control blood pressure and cholesterol even more aggressively.4. Check a high sensitivity CRP to gauge the level of inflammation in your body, as this could contribute to heart attacks.5. If you were a patient in my clinic, I would also recommend starting a low dose (81mg) aspirin.I do not think another stress test would be helpful at this point.  A coronary calcium CT might help you further stratify your risk, but I do not it would ultimately change your risk profile.  Good Luck.

question: My brother has recent had a massive coronary with congestive heart failure. Angiogram shows 4 blocked arteries - 100%, 90%, 80% and 60%. By pass is not an option. He is 51, long time smoker, obese and may have had HBP. I am 55, obese, Non-smoker with HBP for 15 years but on meds and under control for this time. Our father died at 47 of heart attack. Our mother died of heart attack in her sleep at age 89. Her sisters all still alive into 90's and 80's. On fathers side all males died before 55 - women into 70's. I had a thallium stress test  8 years ago and was told I was fine. What options should I discuss with my doctir?
title: should I be tested after a sibling's heart attack?
